Rep. Juandalynn Givan, D-Birmingham, walks across the floor of the Alabama House of Representatives on April 9, 2025 at the Alabama Statehouse in Montgomery, Alabama. Givan pre-filed a bill that would require defendants of rape and incest to get a vasectomy or be castrated if the crime resulted in pregnancy. (Brian Lyman/Alabama Reflector)An Alabama lawmaker has pre-filed a bill for the 2026 legislative session that would require those convicted of rape and incest that results in a pregnancy to get a vasectomy or be castrated.
HB 46, sponsored by Rep. Juandalynn Givan, D-Birmingham, would also allow a mother to get an abortion under the same circumstances. Givan said in an interview Wednesday that the bill is more about the broader conversation of bodily autonomy.
“We have already set a double standard,” Givan said. “Have you seen a bill crafted that tells a man what he cannot, what he can’t and cannot do with his body? You have not, outside of the standard laws that speaks to rape and incest, and we already know that that is definitely a crime.”
SUBSCRIBE: GET THE MORNING HEADLINES DELIVERED TO YOUR INBOX
Robin Marty, a longtime abortion advocate and executive director of a clinic that was once Alabama’s largest abortion provider, opposes the bill.
“As somebody who spends all of her time helping people access reproductive health care, It is just as terrible to create a bill that would take away the reproductive autonomy of a man as it is to have no abortion allowed for a person who can become pregnant,” Marty said in an interview Wednesday afternoon.
In 2020, Rep. Rolanda Hollis, D-Birmingham, sponsored legislation that would require a man to get a vasectomy within a month of his 50th birthday or the birth of his third biological child. It was not considered. The Alabama chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union opposed the legislation, though it did not cite a specific reason for opposition.
ACLU referred comments to the Southern Poverty Law Center, who did not have an expert available. 
Givan’s bill would apply the punishment regardless of the defendant’s age. She said that there needs to be more accountability on those convicted of sex crimes.
“If we can certainly tell a woman what to do with her body, then we should be able to tell a man he should be held accountable for what he does with his,” Givan said. 
Marty agreed with Givan’s sentiment on accountability, but said that can’t be achieved by causing more harm.
“That’s not a wrong that can be fixed by saying ‘here, look, we’re going to harm you as well,’” Marty said.
The Legislature begins its 2026 session in January.

name: Nevada Current
title: Democracy is sounding an alarm. Is America putting it on snooze?
description: As the United States approaches its 250th birthday, the tethers that bind it to the principles of democracy, enshrined in the Constitution by its founders, are being tested in unprecedented fashion. President Donald Trump, wielding power in a manner “like no one has ever seen” as the president likes to say, is riding roughshod over […]
text:
Donald Trump in the Oval Office meeting with congressional leaders on Sept. 30, the eve of the federal government shutdown, with Trump 2028 hats on the Resolute Desk. Trump is constitutionally prohibited from running for reelection in 2028. (Photo posted on Trump's Truth Social account)As the United States approaches its 250th birthday, the tethers that bind it to the principles of democracy, enshrined in the Constitution by its founders, are being tested in unprecedented fashion. President Donald Trump, wielding power in a manner “like no one has ever seen” as the president likes to say, is riding roughshod over the tenets that have come to define the nation. 
Some of Trump’s acts, such as eviscerating cultural and civic norms – rewriting history by editing exhibits at the Smithsonian Museum, commandeering the Kennedy Center Honors, and holding a cage match at the White House to celebrate a national milestone – are extreme, though not illegal. 
Others, such as demanding voter rolls from states, seeking the prosecution of political enemies, and unilaterally raising taxes on Americans via tariffs, appear to violate the law.
Less than a year into his second term, Trump has: 

Issued false emergency declarations in order to deploy military troops to Los Angeles, and the National Guard to Washington, D.C., Memphis, Chicago, and Portland, Oregon;
violated federal law at least six times by withholding funding previously authorized by Congress;
called for the arrest of Democratic lawmakers who urged service members and intelligence officials to disobey illegal orders, calling it ““SEDITIOUS BEHAVIOR, punishable by DEATH!” on his social media platform; and,
welcomed to the White House the Saudi crown prince, who the U.S. found to be responsible for the dismemberment of an American journalist. 

Americans, lulled into complacency by Trump’s “truly masterful flood the zone with shit strategy,” have been slow to awaken to the panoply of threats posed by the president, says UNLV Associate Professor of Political Science, Rebecca Gill. “It is just too much for any one person to keep track of the ways in which this administration is flat out violating laws.”
The resulting exhaustion and complacency have invoked the metaphor of the frog who remains in gradually heating water, unaware of its impending doom. 
“Many Americans — including people in positions of power — remain far too complacent about the threat,” the New York Times wrote in an opinion piece. 
An assessment of America’s journey toward autocracy from the Steady State, a group of more than 300 former intelligence officials who once trained their expert eyes on foreign regimes, finds “unmistakable warning signs at home.” 
The report concludes that “absent organized resistance” the United States “is likely to continue along a path of accelerating democratic erosion, risking further consolidation of executive dominance and a loss of credibility as a model of democracy abroad.”
Pathway to autocracy
“Countries that slide from democracy toward autocracy tend to follow similar patterns,” says the New York Times piece that gauges whether democracy is eroding in America, based on a dozen markers. “The sobering reality is that the United States has regressed, to different degrees, on all 12.” America is “still not close to being a true autocracy, in the mold of Russia or China. But once countries begin taking steps away from democracy, the march often continues.” 
The Steady State analysis identifies five trends that indicate America is moving toward autocracy. 
The first is the consolidation of executive overreach “through governance by decree and weaponization of the state, combining sweeping executive orders and expansive emergency claims with politicized control of the civil service and oversight bodies, the targeting of perceived opponents via justice and intelligence functions, and preferential protection of allies.”
Trump has publicly directed Attorney General Pam Bondi to prosecute political foes, including former FBI chief James Comey, former National Security Advisor John Bolton, and New York Attorney General Letitia James.  
(Photo: Jeniffer Solis/Nevada Current)
“He is attempting to put people in jail for either prosecuting him or for defecting against him,” says Gill of UNLV. “The big targets are either people who attempted to hold him accountable legally, or they are current or former Republicans. He is much more willing than most to go very hard on co-partisans that betray him.”
Retired Nevada Supreme Court Justice Michael Cherry says he’s not convinced the president is targeting political foes. 
“What he went through when they indicted him on all this stuff. It’s tough. Who knows? He’s a human being,” Cherry said during an interview. “He’s got constitutional rights, not only as a human being, but as the president. I don’t know. That’s up to the courts.”
Cherry notes that James “ran on ‘I’m going to prosecute Trump.’ And she did, and now he responds with ‘Well, I’m going to get Letitia and some others.’ So it’s a tough question.”
Federal and state prosecutors have resigned in protest or been fired for refusing to do Trump’s bidding. 
On Wednesday, Lindsey Halligan, Trump’s former personal attorney who was handpicked by the president to charge Comey when other prosecutors declined, was grilled by a judge regarding her failure to follow basic criminal procedures in procuring an indictment against Comey. 
Comey and James, who is also being prosecuted by Halligan, argue that her appointment violates the law. 
Federal judge rules Chattah is ineligible as Acting U.S. attorney to prosecute cases

A similar issue plagues Trump’s Nevada appointee, Sigal Chattah, who has remained in office, jeopardizing prosecutions, even though her appointment as U.S. attorney expired in July. 
Trump has doled out commutations and pardons, based more on fealty than merit. He commuted the sentence of former Congressman George Santos, noting that in the House, he voted Republican. He has not ruled out pardons for Jeffrey Epstein’s accomplice Ghislaine Maxwell, who vouched for Trump’s gentlemanly behavior, or former acquaintance and convicted domestic abuser Sean Combs. 
On his first day in office this year, Trump pardoned more than 1,500 Jan. 6 insurrectionists.
The president granted federal pardons to Nevada’s fake electors, although they faced no federal charges.
Also on his first day in office, Trump issued an executive order declaring there are two sexes.
“They’re building a society without transgender people,” says Rockathena Brittain, a transgender woman. “This was all done in Nazi Germany. They’re saying ‘hey, you’re stuck with the gender assigned at birth.” 
The Trump administration, she says, “has restricted our existence. It’s untethered from reality, and terrifying when you think of the implications.” 
A compliant court
Another sign of eroding democracy, according to the Steady State, is the erosion of judicial independence, “not only through partisan appointments, but through strategic reliance on the Supreme Court’s ‘shadow docket,’ efforts to curtail judicial remedies and intimidate the legal profession, and selective compliance with court rulings.”
The Supreme Court’s ‘shadow docket’ consists of rulings on motions for emergency relief from lower court rulings. They are necessary, says Gill, to accommodate true emergencies, such as a stay of execution. 
“The cases getting decided are no longer emergencies, at least not in any recognizable sense,” says Gill. “The administration has essentially turned this necessary emergency provision into a back door it can use to get lower courts to back off and to violate the law for a little bit longer.”
Gill says she’s most concerned about cases such as the one involving birthright citizenship, in which the courts are “precluding states from protecting these rights.” 
In the court’s  2024/2025 session, the shadow docket “swallowed the Court, both in terms of workload and even practical importance,” says former Solicitor General Gregory G. Garre.
“Precedent allows us to keep stability and predictability in the law,” Gill notes, adding the justices have substituted their own interpretation of the Constitution, which she says is “a very disingenuous way to read something into it like presidential immunity of the scope that they provided. It just isn’t there.”
“Our emergency docket should never be used, as it has been this year, to permit what our own precedent bars,” Justice Elana Kagan wrote in a dissent in September to the president’s effort to fire federal regulators without cause. “Still more, it should not be used, as it also has been, to transfer government authority from Congress to the President, and thus to reshape the Nation’s separation of powers.”
Shadow docket rulings have enabled the deportation of migrants without due process; racial targeting by law enforcement; access to citizen’s confidential data; the elimination of $4 billion in foreign aid, which is resulting in a resurgence of terror; the rejection of transgender individuals from the military; the mass termination of federal employees; and the removal of Democrats from regulatory boards and commissions. 
“Perhaps the degradation of our rule-of-law regime would happen anyway,” Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson wrote in July. “But this Court’s complicity in the creation of a culture of disdain for lower courts, their rulings, and the law (as they interpret it) will surely hasten the downfall of our governing institutions, enabling our collective demise.”
The Supreme Court has ultimate responsibility to uphold constitutional checks and balances on Trump. Gill is skeptical about the court’s ability to hold the line, citing its presidential immunity ruling and what she calls the shadow docket’s misuse. 
Cherry says the shadow docket is not a burden on lower courts. “They’re not final decisions. They’re waiting to have sufficient briefing and argument on these issues, and I would assume that Trump’s going to win some and lose some. That’s what always happens,” he said. 
“While the orders are technically temporary, they have had broad practical effects, allowing the administration to deport tens of thousands of people, discharge transgender military service members, fire thousands of government workers and slash federal spending,” the NYT wrote in October.
Coequal branch?
The third sign that democracy is threatened is Congress’ abdication of its responsibility, resulting in a diminished capacity “to serve as a coequal branch, as delegation, obstruction, and polarization undermine effective oversight,” says the Steady State’s report.
Last week, the House and the Senate voted nearly unanimously to release investigative files on Jeffrey Epstein, after months of Republican efforts to keep the files confidential. The about-face came just days after Trump, who called the effort to release the files “a hoax.” gave Republicans permission to do so. The Epstein saga illustrates the impotence of Republican lawmakers who are beholden, out of loyalty or fear, to Trump’s edicts, some contend. 
Democrats, on the other hand, have waffled between vows to hold Trump and his acolytes accountable, and what critics call feeble efforts to appear bipartisan. 
Congress has been mostly silent as Americans drown in debt exacerbated by Trump’s tariffs, and face the loss of health insurance, thanks to Trump’s One Big Beautiful Bill. 
Bedrock of democracy
The fourth sign of eroding democracy, the Steady State writes, is the makeover of the electoral system by restricting voting, gerrymandering, contesting elections, and “undermining the expectation that elections will be fairly run and their outcomes accepted.”
Trump, who has long complained of rigged elections, attempted to squeeze a few more  Republican House members out of Texas by having congressional districts redrawn. The effort hit a wall last week when a judicial panel blocked the move, finding the maps were “racially gerrymandered.” 
The strategy could now backfire on Trump, as California voters gave that state their blessing to redraw districts to counter the threat posed by Texas.
In March, Trump issued an executive order requiring states to turn over their voter rolls to the Department of Justice, ostensibly in an effort to expose those registered in multiple states. 
In July, Nevada provided a version of its statewide voter registration list that is generally available to the public. In August, the Civil Rights Division again requested full access to Nevada’s complete statewide voter registration list, including sensitive personal information.
Forever obsessed with his 2020 loss, Trump’s trying to bigfoot all over Nevada’s election system

The next month, Nevada responded that it would conduct an analysis of the legal authority for the government’s request.  In September, Nevada Secretary of State Cisco Aguilar refused to share the complete voter registration list, contending the DOJ request was unjustified. 
“The DOJ has authority to ensure states have proper registration procedures and programs to ensure clean voter roles,” says Eileen O’Connor, a former attorney in the Justice Department’s Civil Rights Division and an expert for the Brennan Center, which is tracking states’ responses to the DOJ request. “I would say that sweeping up all of the voter rolls around the country far exceeds its authority.” 
Voter rolls, she says, provide a snapshot that is outdated before it could be of use to track down fraudulent registration.  The federal government “is attempting to play a role that it does not have and is not permitted to have, in running elections. This appears to be a concerted effort on the part of the current administration to sort of take over federal elections.”
Trump, who has floated the prospect of seeking a third term, even as he acknowledges he can’t, has made his tolerance for election interference apparent by pardoning the insurrectionists who rioted to keep him in the White House after his 2020 defeat. 
“Quiet, piggy.”
America’s greatest threat, Trump has repeatedly asserted, is “the enemy within” – non-adherents who are either Democrats, wayward Republicans, minorities, or LGBTQ+ individuals. He plans to use American cities as a training ground for the U.S. military to address the threat they pose. 
The undermining of public trust and knowledge “through attacks on the press, academia, watchdog institutions, and dissenting voices,” is the final threat identified in the Steady State’s assessment of eroding democracy.  “Together, these trends indicate a restructuring of the constitutional order around personal loyalty rather than adherence to law.”
“The strategy for authoritarianism is to get people to stop looking for the truth,” says Gill. 
“They try to obfuscate so much and tell so many different lies that often contradict each other. People give up believing in a knowable truth.” 
On the first day of his second term, Trump issued an executive order restoring freedom of speech and ending federal censorship. Since then, Trump has extorted law firms, universities, and media outlets for speech of which he disapproves. He has decried labels directed at him such as ‘authoritarian’ and ‘fascist’ while declaring hatred for Democrats at a rally and at a memorial service for slain podcaster Charlie Kirk.  
Trump’s tirades are often directed at journalists, who he openly maligns for asking questions. 
Earlier this month, on Air Force One, Trump cut off a Bloomberg News reporter who asked why he had not yet released the Epstein files.
“Quiet, piggy!” the president barked.
Last week, Trump berated an ABC reporter who asked about murdered journalist Jamal Khashoggi during the Saudi crown prince’s visit to the Oval Office. Trump deemed her question as “insubordinate” and called ABC a “crappy company,” adding its broadcasting licenses “should be taken away” and that FCC chairman Brendan Carr, who regulates broadcasters “should look at that.” 
Carr is best known for using the language of a mob boss when he said the government could deal with late night talk show host Jimmy Kimmel’s monologues about Trump “the easy way or the hard way.” Trump praised Carr’s threat, and said yanking the licenses of networks, who he says are “97% against me,” was up to Carr. 
“What a stupid thing for him to do,” says former Nevada Supreme Court Justice Cherry. “These are business decisions. The government should stay out of this stuff.” 
Last week, Trump called for NBC to fire Seth Meyers. 
While Trump appears to have forgotten his order to end government censorship, Attorney General Bondi was poised earlier this year to “target” Americans for hate speech. Bondi, informed that hate speech is not prohibited in America, backed off. The episode rankled the MAGAverse, as well as Democrats. 
Cherry, a seasoned jurist and a Democrat, finds merit in Bondi’s intention. 
“I’m a proponent of the First Amendment,” he said, adding that as “an American Jew, I’m worried about hate speech. It’s frightening for our kids to be bullied, and hate speech can cause bullying.”
Free speech, he says, should be protected. “But we’ve got to do something about hate speech,” including, he says, from Trump, who he says “gets carried away. It’s got to stop, period. No matter who you are. You’ve got to be kind to your enemies.”

Cracks in the foundation
By his own admission, Trump could “shoot somebody” and get away with it, or assault a woman by grabbing her genitals, because “when you’re a star they let you do it. You can do anything.” 
Trump, during his first term, and even more so in his second, has bathed in the warm waters of infallibility, extending the duration of his self-proclaimed dictatorship from its designated first-day to its 11th month.  
Congress and the Supreme Court, critics contend, have abandoned checks and balances in favor of furthering Trump’s agenda. But in recent weeks, chinks have appeared in the president’s armor. 
Last month, the long-silent Senate voiced disapproval of Trump’s tariffs in a series of votes. 
Trump’s use of his power to enrich himself, his family and friends is also grating on some Republicans, as is his penchant for living in luxury, even in the people’s house, where he took a wrecking ball to the East Wing to make way for an extravagant ballroom, and remodeled the Lincoln bathroom in marble and gold. 
Last week, Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, one of Trump’s fiercest defenders until now, apologized for “toxic” political behavior, called out Trump for falsehoods after he called her a traitor, and on Friday announced she was quitting Congress in January. “I refuse to be a battred wife,” she said, referring to Trump’s tirades. 
The break up preceded Trump’s capitulation on releasing the Epstein files. A majority of Republicans disagree with Trump’s handling of the issue, a rare instance in the MAGA world. By contrast, a majority of Republicans supported Trump’s handling of the Jan. 6 insurrection. 
Trump contends he is operating within the confines of the Constitution to carry out the will of those who elected him. Recent polls, however, indicate an increasing awareness and rejection of the president’s penchant for exceeding his authority. 
Even the Supreme Court, which empowered Trump with an unprecedented declaration of immunity, and has indulged his efforts to test the bounds of his authority, is signaling skepticism of the president’s authority to impose tariffs absent congressional approval.
Trump’s power grab could emerge as an issue in the midterms, when Gov. Joe Lombardo will be on the ballot. An Emerson College Polling survey indicates Trump’s approval rating in Nevada is 39%, and his disapproval rating is 54%,leaving the president with a net approval rating of -15. 
Lombardo announces reelection campaign, warns against a Democrat in power 

Lombardo gushed this month after receiving a second endorsement from Trump. His campaign did not respond when asked whether Nevadans’ concerns about Trump could cut into Lombardo’s votes. 
Nevada Attorney General Aaron Ford, a Democrat who has joined attorneys general from blue states in filing 36 lawsuits against the Trump administration, is hoping to unseat Lombardo. 
Lombardo and Trump, he said in a statement “are Nevada’s biggest roadblocks to affordability. I will always put Nevada families first. That’s why I have sued both the Trump and Biden administrations and am fighting to lower costs and make Nevada more affordable.”
Washoe County Commission Chairwoman Alexis Hill, who is running in the Democratic primary against Ford, says the governor’s veto of a bill that would have allowed for open primaries is in line with Trump’s efforts to disenfranchise voters. 
“That’s 38% of the electorate,” she said. “He’s essentially saying that they can’t participate in the democracy of Nevada.” Voters rejected a similar measure last year. 
Hill says Nevadans she encounters are “worried about ensuring that we uphold democratic ideals, but are also worried about livability and affordability.” 
Trump, following Democratic election wins this month, retrieved from the back burner his own campaign promise to bring down prices. “The new word is ‘affordability,” he said during an Oval Office meeting Friday with New York Mayor-Elect Zohran Mamdani. Last week he hailed McDonald’s as a symbol of American affordability, and proclaimed he’s “normalized” inflation.
Trump’s end game is unknown, and may depend on the alacrity of a citizenry that is largely bleary-eyed and overwhelmed. The demise of authoritarian regimes, experts say, most often result from military defeat, economic collapse, or resistance movements that offer an alternative and capitalize on unrest.
Americans are beginning to notice the erosion of democracy as it “starts to impact their everyday lives in ways that they can’t rationalize, particularly when they cannot assign the blame anywhere else,” says Gill.  “Masked federal agents are kidnapping folks off the street. Citizenship doesn’t matter. We’re handing people over to terrorist prison camps in other countries with no due process. A lot of people have woken up to this.”
Turning that awakening into a movement could be challenging, she says.
Trump’s team “has done its homework” and studied similar transitions, like those involving Russian dictator Vladimir Putin and Hungary’s Viktor Orban. “They have started to gobble up alternative and mainstream media. They’ve essentially gone to war against any source of truth.”

name: Alabama Reflector
title: The small fights for democracy are the epics of our time
description: A few weeks ago, I read “Gilgamesh” and “Beowulf.” I hadn’t read either before. But I knew the broad strokes of the stories. Gilgamesh is the tale of a Mesopotamian king and demigod who befriends a wild man; sees and grieves the wild man’s death and begins a quest for immortality. The surprise for a […]
text:
Thousands of demonstrators march through downtown Birmingham, Ala., during the "No Kings" protest on Saturday, Oct. 18, 2025. The protests against the Trump administration drew thousands of people around Alabama. (Andi Rice for Alabama Reflector)A few weeks ago, I read “Gilgamesh” and “Beowulf.”
I hadn’t read either before. But I knew the broad strokes of the stories. Gilgamesh is the tale of a Mesopotamian king and demigod who befriends a wild man; sees and grieves the wild man’s death and begins a quest for immortality. The surprise for a modern reader (in Sophus Helle’s translation) is that Gilgamesh is clearly a tyrant and sexual abuser, even by the standards of the third millennium B.C.
Like the best poetry, you can find different meanings in the verses. You have a powerful man reaching his limits. And a thug getting his comeuppance. But either way, Gilgamesh learns there are boundaries not even the most ruthless can cross.
SUBSCRIBE: GET THE MORNING HEADLINES DELIVERED TO YOUR INBOX
I also knew the arc of Beowulf. Monster eats Danes; Superstrong Dane meets Monster; Monster loses arm, etc. But I didn’t expect the poem to be so somber.
Beowulf flexes his might against beasts and dragons, but in front of a backdrop of loss and decay. The work ends not in triumph, but with a funeral, and Beowulf’s people mourning his death.  It’s an unsettling ending. Monsters are inevitable. Heroes are not.
But maybe subconsciously I’ve been drawn to these stories of powerful people encountering restraints. Just look around. Neither the law nor common decency seem to be holding our elites back these days.
Nor can I shake a sense of decline. Last year, I wondered where we would be on Thanksgiving 2025, as a new administration committed to attacking immigrants, gutting health care and undermining democracy took shape.
So, with the holiday near, let’s take stock of Alabama.
Our leaders and institutions, like many around the country, have all but knuckled under. No one should ever expect courage from this state’s congressional delegation. But the Republican members’ grovelling to this administration stands out.
It would be bad enough if all we had were their smiles at the terror unleashed on immigrants. But they’ve also kept their peace — and sometimes cheered — as Trump has pursued a trade policy ruinous to Alabama farms and businesses.
Gov. Kay Ivey has supported Trump’s efforts to dismantle the U.S. Department of Education, which feeds thousands of Alabama school children every day. The entire GOP leadership seems indifferent to the soaring price of health insurance, which leaves hundreds of thousands of Alabamians at risk of losing it entirely.
Our two flagship universities have been notably craven. The University of Alabama sat on its hands this spring as Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agents kidnapped Alireza Douroudi, a graduate student from Iran studying engineering, and left him to suffer in a Louisiana prison.
Auburn University fired multiple employees this September for alleged insensitivity to the killing of far-right activist Charlie Kirk. This concern for civility did not prevent Auburn from welcoming far-right U.S. Sen. Tommy Tuberville to campus, a man who has called city dwellers “rats” and immigrants “garbage,” and also claimed that Black Americans “do the crime.”
All this weakness would be enough to make one despair.
But then we see the courage of individual Alabamians.
Families of immigrants fight for their loved ones, often at great personal risk, against a system that does nothing but create suffering.
Librarians continue to battle for our right to read books in the face of official fearmongering and censorship.
And there are Alabamians who come out for their values. Whether they’re crowding a room to stick up for public broadcasting or gathering by the thousands in the name of democracy.
It reminds me of another poem I’ve read recently, by the early 19th century Irish bard Antaine Raiftearai. It’s not about immortality or dragons. It’s a long outburst of glee at Raiftearai’s preferred candidate winning a local election. In the middle of dunking on the vanquished, the poet wrote:
Is aimsir an chruatain gur sheas na fíréin. Roughly, “in the time of struggle stood the righteous.”
We will not emerge from this season of hardship because a hero came over the sea to beat someone up. The battles we face are in thousands of ordinary places, over values we once thought moot.
We will save what is good about America when thousands of people will draw lines against authoritarianism in their daily lives and refuse to budge. Democracy and the rule of law will prevail if Alabamians — as they have in the past — stand against those who would destroy both.
So I’m grateful to those who rise to fight, in battles big and small. They alone won’t bring the abuses or the suffering to an immediate halt. But they will put us on a path away from it, toward something better. Something more reflective of who we are.
The fight for democracy is the epic of our time. We see the monsters. And in the people standing for our ideals, we find the heroes.

name: Connecticut Mirror
title: What to know about CT laws relating to ICE interactions
description: CT recently made changes to the laws governing how local and state officials interact with ICE and limiting what ICE can do in the state.
text:
The Connecticut legislature recently made changes to the laws governing how local and state officials interact with U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents and limiting what ICE agents can do in the state. The revisions to state law were made in response to residents’ concerns about federal immigration policy. Divided along party lines, state Democrats have worked to address immigrants’ assertions that they are living in fear.
Here’s what you need to know about what ICE can do in Connecticut. 
What changes were made in the latest state legislation?
In November’s special session, state lawmakers passed House Bill 8004 which included sections that limit ICE from making arrests at courthouses. The bill prohibits representatives of a local, state or federal law enforcement authority from arresting people inside state courthouses without a judicial warrant. ICE agents are also not allowed to wear masks on courthouse grounds without a medical requirement. 
There are also measures to protect immigrants’ personal information. State agencies are not allowed to share personal information such as dates and times of court hearings and appointments, home addresses, and workplaces. 
Gov. Ned Lamont signed the bill into law shortly after the special session.
Can Connecticut law enforcement turn immigrants over to ICE?
In 2019, Connecticut lawmakers passed the Trust Act, which specified the grounds on which local and state officials are allowed to turn over unauthorized migrants to ICE. The Act prohibits state law enforcement from arresting individuals solely on the basis of detainers — requests from ICE to hold someone for up to 48 hours so agents can then pick them up. 
Law enforcement officers may comply with detainers only if ICE has a judicial warrant to make an arrest, or if the individual in their custody has been convicted of a class A or B felony, or identified on a terrorist watch list. Class A or B felonies include murder, kidnapping, sexual assault, robbery, and first-degree manslaughter. 
The Trust Act was modified in May of this year. Now, individuals can sue cities and towns if the Act is violated. Further, the circumstances under which law enforcement must comply with ICE requests for detainment were expanded to include 13 more crimes and broaden who is considered a law enforcement official. 
What happens when ICE makes an arrest?
While the recent laws intended to make courthouses safer for immigrants in Connecticut, ICE agents can still make arrests in other public areas without a warrant if they have a reasonable suspicion to believe that the individual they are targeting is an unauthorized migrant, as per the Immigration and Nationality Act.
Further, aside from courthouse grounds, there are no laws requiring ICE agents to show their face, or prohibiting masks. This means that ICE agents may still approach an individual in a mask and make an arrest, without a warrant.
How does the state recommend state agencies respond to ICE visits?
In a document from Lamont’s office issued in January, the state provides guidance on how state agencies should handle visits from ICE to comply with state and federal laws while also protecting individuals’ privacy rights. 
The guide instructs state officials to request information on why the ICE agent is making a visit, notify legal counsel, and refrain from sharing any personal information or documents such as immigration status until a legal counsel reviews the request. 
ICE also has limited access to non-public areas. They are prohibited from accessing non-public areas of a state agency building without a judicial warrant. But there is no legislation to limit their movements in public premises of an establishment. For example, an ICE agent could make an unwarranted arrest on a sidewalk outside of the state facility.

name: Michigan Advance
title: Field shaping up in Michigan’s contested U.S. Senate race
description: The battle for retiring U.S. Sen. Gary Peters’s seat in the upper chamber of Congress is gearing up to include at least one potentially messy primary on the Democratic Party side and a potentially bruising fight on the GOP side if a new challenge to the party’s frontrunner causes intra-party friction. Peters announced in January […]
text:
The U.S. Capitol on the evening of Tuesday, Sept. 30, 2025, just hours before a federal government shutdown. (Photo by Ashley Murray/States Newsroom)The battle for retiring U.S. Sen. Gary Peters’s seat in the upper chamber of Congress is gearing up to include at least one potentially messy primary on the Democratic Party side and a potentially bruising fight on the GOP side if a new challenge to the party’s frontrunner causes intra-party friction.
Peters announced in January that he wouldn’t be running for a sixth term in the U.S. Senate, setting up an open seat and race that has invited big money and national attention. Republicans will be fighting tooth and nail to maintain their majority in 2026, and see Michigan as a big opportunity to either hold or expand their grasp on the chamber.
The race is currently rated as a toss-up.
Meanwhile, Democrats, coming off a big sweep of wins this November, are seeing the political tide rising against the administration of President Donald Trump and his most controversial policies affecting immigration, the wars in Israel and Ukraine, proposed new conflicts in Latin America and a failing economy. Holding on to Peters’ seat could be a key piece to standing the party’s ground and potentially taking back control of the upper chamber.
Here’s Michigan Advance’s breakdown of the race thus far, the support each candidate has received and current fundraising totals.
The Democrats
For the Democrats eyeing that prize, a hotly contested primary is on the horizon. In the race are U.S. Rep. Haley Stevens of Birmingham, state Sen. Mallory McMorrow of Royal Oak, Abdul El-Sayed, former director of the Wayne County Department of Health, Human and Veterans Services, and research health specialist Rachel Howard.
Stevens has positioned herself as the frontrunner and much of the party’s political machine is supporting her bid for the Senate. But El-Sayed and McMorrow are both on her tail in terms of fundraising. Howard hasn’t gotten the same amount of attention, but could make some waves if she is able to stay in the race down the stretch.
U.S. Rep. Haley Stevens (D-Birmingham) speaks out against proposed cuts at the Social Security Administration during a rally in Detroit on April 4, 2025. | Kyle Davidson/Michigan Advance
Haley Stevens 
Stevens is the establishment party fixture in the race, and has routinely been noted as one of the most effective Democrats in Washington, D.C. Several top news sources, including Politico, Semafor and Axios, have all noted that she is being privately backed by the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, U.S. Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer and other top Democrats. That support has not been made public, however, as leadership and the party machine typically holds off boosting its candidates until after the primary.
Stevens’ Michigan U.S. Senate bid gets a boost from pro-Israel political action committee

Stevens has also received large sums of money through the years from the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, or AIPAC, and it’s likely that the group will spend on her behalf against her opponents. Stevens is one of the stronger pro-Israel Democrats in the U.S. House and now has the backing of the Democratic Majority for Israel PAC, or DMFI.
Stevens also has a long list of supporters, from former governors, her colleagues in Michigan; U.S. Reps. Hillary Scholten and Shri Thanedar, several sitting state representatives, the Michigan Black Caucus, UNITE HERE Local 24, UA Local 636 and the Teamsters Local 243.
Campaign finance disclosures in the Federal Election Committee database in the latest October quarterly report shows Stevens is leading the pack with $4.72 million raised, $2.1 million spent and $2.61 million cash on hand.
Michigan state Sen. Mallory McMorrow, D-Royal Oak, speaks at Tenacity Brewing in Flint, Mich., during a stop on her U.S. Senate campaign’s “McMorrow On Tap Brewery Tour” on June 21, 2025. (Photo by Andrew Roth/Michigan Advance)
Mallory McMorrow 
McMorrow made a name for herself standing up to Republicans who have gone after Michigan’s LGBTQ+ community, namely state Sen. Lana Theis of Brighton, who evoked  anti-LGBTQ+ rhetoric in a 2022 invocation, which led to a Democratic walkout and criticism of Theis on social media. Theis accused McMorrow and other Democrats of “grooming” for their support for teaching kids about LGBTQ+ issues. 
Theis specifically named McMorrow in a fundraising email, to which McMorrow punched back in a scathing Michigan Senate floor speech. That raised McMorrow’s national profile, and she appeared as a speaker at the Democratic National Convention in 2024.
That helped McMorrow launch her U.S. Senate bid this year, where she has become one of the key alternatives to Stevens for Michigan Democrats seeking to support a less establishment candidate. McMorrow’s support has come from a long list of Michigan state representatives and senators, local officials, UA Local 370, Nurses for America and The Next 50, which supports young Democratic leaders in the making.
Campaign finance disclosures in the Federal Election Committee database in the latest October quarterly report shows McMorrow just behind Stevens with $3.85 million raised, $2.4 million spent and $1.45 million cash on hand.
Michigan Democratic U.S. Senate candidate Abdul El-Sayed speaks to students on the campus of Michigan State University. Nov. 18, 2025 | Photo by Ben Solis/Michigan Advance
Abdul El-Sayed 
El-Sayed is the stalwart progressive candidate in the race, a student of the game set in play by U.S. Sen. Bernie Sanders, the independent from Vermont, who regularly champions Medicare for All (of note, El-Sayed wrote a book on the policy). As the son of an Egyptian immigrant, he was also one of the earliest candidates in the race to call the actions of the Israeli government in its war against Hamas and the Palestinian people a genocide, which set him apart from his opponents before McMorrow also landed on the position.
The candidate previously ran for governor in Michigan in 2018, but ultimately lost in the primary to current term-limited Michigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer. Following that race, El-Sayed became the director of the Wayne County Department of Health, Human and Veterans Services, focusing on the wellness of Detroit and its surrounding metropolitan areas.
El-Sayed has the support of Sanders, U.S. Rep. Rashida Tlaib of Detroit, former Michigan congressman Andy Levin, party fixtures like Keith Ellison, the attorney general of Minnesota, progressive-minded sitting and former state legislators, and some local officials across the state. He’s also garnered the support from a swath of younger voters and key Michigan Democratic Party groups, like its grassroots caucus, the LGBT&A caucus and its progressive caucus.
Former Congressman Andy Levin endorses El-Sayed’s U.S. Senate bid in joint op-ed

Campaign finance disclosures in the Federal Election Committee database in the latest October quarterly report show El-Sayed with $3.57 million raised, $1.72 million spent and $1.84 million cash on hand.
Rachel Howard
Howard, who hails herself as a non-politican, is a combat veteran with the Michigan National Guard who was deployed to Iraq and Afghanistan, and a clinical researcher at Henry Ford Health. There has been no significant polling showing Howard in matchups against the others in the primary. She has raised $10,937 thus far, spent $6,171 and has $4,766 cash on hand.
Her policy positions appear to be that of a more moderate choice, like Stevens, in the race. She supports both Israel and Palestine in the conflict but said that while she backs peaceful coexistence, she does not support the Israeli government’s actions that have harmed civilians. She believes Ukraine has a right to its sovereignty. 
She believes abortion decisions should be between a patient and their doctor, but also has said reducing the need for abortions by addressing root causes was necessary. She also strongly supports the Second Amendment but would fight gun violence through safe storage laws, background checks, violence prevention and training. She supports a single payer healthcare system, much like McMorrow.
Howard has also called for banning corporate donations and keeping big money out of politics. 
The Republicans
Republicans in the state party and on the national scene have by and large thrown their weight behind former U.S. Rep. Mike Rogers of White Lake, who has been endorsed by Trump, has money of his own to invest and is seeing the donor class rally around him. 
But his apparent coronation before primary season really begins could face some speed bumps. 
His biggest potential rival, if she can make the ballot and pull away grassroots voters, is former Michigan Republican Party Co-Chair Bernadette Smith, who resigned from the party earlier this month and officially launched her candidacy on Thursday. It is unlikely that Smith can pull away Trump World from Rogers, but if he seems vulnerable, things could change. Aside from Smith, dentist Kent Benham and activist Geneieve Scott are also eyeing to take down Rogers in the primary, but their chances are slim.
Michigan Republican candidate for the U.S. Senate Mike Rogers speaks ahead of former President Donald Trump at a campaign event in Detroit on Oct. 18, 2024. (Photo: Anna Liz Nichols)
Mike Rogers 
Rogers is a well-known and battle-ready commodity in Michigan Republican politics. From 2001 to 2015, he represented his mid-Michigan district for seven terms, including ascending to the powerful chair of the House Intelligence Committee. In 2024, he sought to replace former U.S. Sen. Debbie Stabenow of Lansing when she decided to retire after a 24-year career in the upper chamber.
Rogers received strong support from Republicans in the 2024 primary with 60% of the vote and Trump’s endorsement, but he ultimately lost to current U.S. Sen. Elissa Slotkin of Holly in the general election. A year after his defeat, Rogers is back to try and claim a Senate seat and balance the scales after the Democrats have held both Senate seats since 2001.
Rogers strongly supports Israel, abortion policies left up to states and not federal mandate or law, and Trump’s tariff and immigration policies. He opposed key LGBTQ+ rights issues including allowing transgender girls to play in girl’s sports. He has the backing of key U.S. Senate Republican leaders like Majority Leader John Thune, several sitting state lawmakers, local officials, Americans for Prosperity and Associated Builders and Contractors.
Rogers and Slotkin slug it out on Social Security, guns, EVs and abortion in final debate 

Rogers has raised $3.41 million thus far, spent just $966,939 and has a whopping $2.7 million cash on hand.
Bernadette Smith 
Smith’s candidacy comes late to the race, and some have questioned whether she has the infrastructure, money or ability to make the ballot in order to be a player in the primary against Rogers. But with some within the party questioning whether Rogers could win against someone like McMorrow or Stevens, Smith could see an opportunity to make his race to the top a bit more difficult.
Since her campaign was launched Thursday, there is no polling that includes her and she has not had to submit any financial disclosures. She will, soon, however, and that could give Republican voters a better look at who is backing her and if she came to play.
Smith is a tried and true devotee to Trump and has links to Turning Point USA. She spoke at the party’s Capitol-lawn rally for the slain Charlie Kirk following his assassination in September.
Bernadette Smith | Photo from Michigan Republican Party
Kent Benham 
A view into Benham’s policy positions background other than his dental practice are hard to come by. He does not have a campaign website; his only presence is a personal Facebook page that features his practice.
The FEC does not have any campaign finance data listed for him in its system.
Genevieve Scott 
Scott is a Republican activist who was prominent in the “Stop the Steal” movement furthering the 2020 election conspiracy that claimed, without evidence, that Trump won despite former President Joe Biden’s clear victory.
She also reportedly attended the rallies that led up to the January 6, 2021 riot and insurrection attempt at the U.S. Capitol building. Scott urged people to enter the Capitol, Michigan Public reported, but there was no evidence that she actually entered the Capitol during the chaotic event.
She has adopted a Trump-inspired “America First” policy platform, with a focus on promoting American excellence in schools, election integrity and has a “waste, fraud and abuse” mantra that runs like a current through the modern Republican Party in the era of Trump.
Scott has raised $35,544, spent nearly all of that to the tune of $30,636 and has $4,908, a massive burn rate for a candidate with limited funds.

name: New Jersey Monitor
title: NJ bill would ban ICE agents from wearing masks
description: Two New Jersey lawmakers want to follow California's lead and ban ICE agents from masking, a move that would likely end up in court.
text:
Two New Jersey lawmakers want to follow California's lead and ban ICE agents from masking, a move that would likely end up in court. (Photo by Anne-Marie Caruso/New Jersey Monitor)New Jersey lawmakers are behind a push to ban federal and local law enforcement from wearing masks on the job, a move Gov.-elect Mikie Sherrill has said she supports.
Sen. Benjie Wimberly (D-Passaic) said that as the number of U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement raids has escalated in the last 10 months, he’s concerned both about the fear masked agents have instilled in communities with undocumented residents and the danger of criminals using masks to impersonate ICE agents.
“I’m sure somebody is working on a scheme right now about how they can rob some place, posed as ICE agents,” said Wimberly. “It’s very scary times.”
Immigration agents conduct second raid on Newark seafood market

Since President Donald Trump took office and executed his campaign promise of mass detention and deportation, some immigration agents have shown up at schools, businesses, and courts with their faces covered and wearing no identification. It’s a tactic lawmakers said they haven’t seen under previous administrations.
Wimberly’s bill, introduced earlier this month, would bar any law enforcement officer who is interacting with the public from wearing a mask or disguise. Officers who are working undercover, wearing a shield that does not conceal their face, or wearing a medical mask would not be subject to the bill.
Officers who violate the provisions would face fines of $500 to $1,000, prison for up to six months, or both.
Sherrill, a Democrat, said during her campaign for the state’s top job this year that she supports banning police from wearing masks and requiring that they identify themselves during enforcement operations. A Sherrill spokesman did not respond to a request for comment on the bill.
She’s told stories of ICE agents looking like they’re “dressed for Afghanistan” who refuse to identify themselves, calling it “unacceptable.”
“We need to know who is on our streets here in New Jersey,” she said at a campaign stop in Newark last month.
California passed a bill in September that bars law enforcement officers from wearing most masks while carrying out their duties. The U.S. Department of Justice sued the state over the law last week, calling it an unconstitutional attempt to regulate federal agents.
Lawmakers in several other states, including Michigan, New York, Pennsylvania, and Massachusetts, have introduced similar legislation.
The Trump administration has defended ICE agents for masking, claiming agents who show their faces during enforcement operations are harassed and doxed online. A U.S. Department of Homeland Security spokeswoman did not respond to a request for comment on ICE’s mask policy, though a spokeswoman has previously said it would “not abide by a state’s unconstitutional ban.”
Assemblywoman Verlina Reynolds-Jackson (D-Mercer), prime sponsor of the bill in the lower chamber, said the measure protects law enforcement officers by “honoring the person behind the uniform and the badge.”
“We want people to trust police officers. Police officers are supposed to be trusted people in the community,” she said. “You can’t do that if others are coming in under the cloak of protection and they’re really just undermining people’s basic human rights.”
While the bill would also prevent state, county, and local law enforcement from obstructing their faces while interacting with the public, lawmakers agree they’re more focused on getting ICE agents to stop masking.
Ron Chen, a professor of law and former dean of Rutgers Law School, told the New Jersey Monitor last month that a state law banning ICE agents from wearing masks would likely be struck down by courts because states are barred from regulating the federal government.
Wimberly conceded that a court challenge against the measure would be likely if it is signed into law.
“My hope is that, for where we’re at in America, I think we can create a template that should go across every state in America,” Wimberly said.

name: VTDigger
title: Heather Duhamel and Kaitlin Northey: Vermont must protect and strengthen the programs that prepare early childhood educators
description:
Every new classroom that opens needs a qualified early childhood educator to lead it.
Read the story on VTDigger here:  Heather Duhamel and Kaitlin Northey: Vermont must protect and strengthen the programs that prepare early childhood educators.
text:
This commentary is by Heather Duhamel and Kaitlin Northey. Duhamel is assistant professor and program director for early childhood education online at Vermont State University and higher education outreach coordinator for the Vermont Association for the Education of Young Children. Northey is associate professor of early childhood education at the University of Vermont.


The future of Vermont’s child care system depends on access to early childhood teacher education programs, clear and connected preparation pathways, and support for higher ed students to complete them.
Vermont’s child care future depends on the strength of its early childhood education workforce. We’ve made historic gains in expanding access for families, but the system still needs more well-prepared early childhood educators to give our youngest children the best possible start. 
Building a strong child care workforce starts with educating the early childhood educators. Long before caring for your child, your family’s trusted early childhood educator was training to teach young children.
Across Vermont, future educators begin their journeys in high schools, career and technical education programs, apprenticeships, community colleges, certificate programs and universities. This variety is a strength, reflecting the many ways people enter higher ed: as students, parents, mid-career changers and lifelong learners.
And these programs are popular — more high school students are taking ECE courses for college credit, and early childhood education courses are among the highest enrolled at Community College of Vermont.
In our work as teacher educators, we see every day how much these programs strengthen our workforce, and why it’s important to stabilize them in uncertain times. We also see where students stop their studies, and how we can help them continue.
The Vermont Association for the Education of Young Children recently released the first higher ed landscape study since 2017. The report, Higher Ed Pathways, Challenges, and Opportunities for Vermont’s Early Childhood Education Workforce, was researched and written by Heather. 
Her research finds that students need to see connections between today’s coursework, tomorrow’s credential, and how continuing their studies impacts their compensation and career.
There are many ways for early childhood educators to enter higher ed, but many stop credit-bearing coursework after two courses, or six credits. This pattern extends beyond early childhood education, yet because our intro classes are so popular, we have specific opportunities to retain students.
And this is important because Vermont needs more well-prepared early childhood educators. As a state, we’ve invested in helping families afford child care and expanding program access. But every new classroom that opens needs a qualified early childhood educator to lead it.
Institutions are adapting. Flexible scheduling, credit for prior learning and clearer advising tools all help ECEs continue their own education — especially the many who do coursework while working full-time. State investments in scholarships, apprenticeship programs and student loan repayment assistance for early childhood educators are crucial supports.
Yet bachelor’s and graduate-level programs remain fragile. Over the past 10 years, Vermont has lost several early childhood preparation programs, and faculty across the state told us that higher ed institutions are now making changes or reductions to programs in an effort to navigate federal funding uncertainties. 
Federal policy adds urgency. The 2025 national budget reconciliation bill introduced restrictions on federal student loan access for “low-earning” majors. Without action, many students could lose the very loans that make their education possible, jeopardizing both higher education programs and Vermont’s child care workforce.
This threat compounds the ongoing challenge of compensation: historically, early childhood educators earn low wages, while the cost of care for very young children remains high. Without public investment, families shoulder tuition costs and educators endure low wages. Vermont is leading the nation in changing this, but educator compensation is still catching up.
Vermont doesn’t have to accept this outcome.
Federal law uses state‑specific earnings thresholds to define “low-earning,” which means that ensuring early childhood educators are paid according to their qualifications — as in other professions — can protect students’ access to federal loans. This approach strengthens higher ed programs and pathways, attracts new students, and makes early childhood education a viable career choice. Ultimately, it supports stronger child care programs and better outcomes for children and families. 
Here’s what we recommend:

Stabilize early childhood education preparation programs at every level, from high school to graduate school, through consistent funding and policy support.
Make transfer agreements and pathway maps visible and easy to use for students, advisors and faculty.
Strengthen coordination between higher ed, workforce and licensing systems so programs and professional standards align.
Link compensation and advancement to preparation and credentials, so education in this field has tangible value.

These are not abstract policy goals; they’re the foundation of the workforce our child care system depends on. 
We’ve seen firsthand that progress happens when Vermont’s educators, higher ed partners and policymakers work together. Advocacy and partnership have already reshaped child care in Vermont. Now we must sustain that momentum by protecting the programs that support early childhood education careers.
We’ve worked hard to build higher ed systems that welcome aspiring and advancing early childhood educators wherever they are in their coursework and career. These systems show real promise. With the right support, they can grow and retain the child care workforce Vermont depends on.
Read the story on VTDigger here:  Heather Duhamel and Kaitlin Northey: Vermont must protect and strengthen the programs that prepare early childhood educators.

name: New Jersey Monitor
title: The push to punish a NJ school board member for Facebook posts is foolish
description: A Salem County school board member is the target of an ethics complaint for asking her Facebook followers about tax hikes.
text:
A Salem County school board member is the target of an ethics complaint for asking her Facebook followers about tax hikes. (Photo by Anne-Marie Caruso/New Jersey Monitor)Why are New Jerseyans barred from hearing from some of their elected leaders about matters of public concern?
That’s the question at the heart of a new lawsuit filed by a school board member out of Alloway in Salem County who is facing ethics charges because she asked constituents on Facebook what they thought of a potential school tax hike.
“As a resident of Alloway, I am wondering what other residents think about a 9-15% school tax increase?” reads one post from the school board member, Gail Nazarene.
“My personal opinion is 3.3% is the max I can afford,” reads part of another.
Pretty milquetoast, if you ask me, especially if you consider the tons of AI slop and nasty political rants you can find on Facebook at any given moment. But they were enough to trigger an ethics investigation, with one of Nazarene’s colleagues filing a complaint with the state School Ethics Commission that says Nazarene’s posts violate the state School Ethics Act. The complaint, from Alloway school board member Sara Cobb, says Nazarene’s Facebook posts reference potential tax hikes that “were not formally reviewed, adopted, or confirmed by the Board.”
“The publication of these figures created confusion and concern among members of the public, and conveyed the impression that Ms. Nazarene was speaking on behalf of the Board without authorization,” it reads.
Cobb also took issue with another Facebook post where Nazarene asked, “I am ASKING this FOR MYSELF NOT the board. What if taxes went up 20% is that a number you will except (sic)?” Cobb wrote that this and other posts “appear to use the prestige of her Board membership to promote a specific budgetary narrative, potentially undermining official communications from the Board or administration.”
You know that old canard “you can’t shout fire in a crowded theater”? Apparently, New Jersey’s version is you can’t potentially undermine the Alloway school district’s communications department.
There’s no state law that explicitly bars school board members from speaking to the public, of course. But the School Ethics Commission has interpreted the School Ethics Act in a way that school board members risk violating it if they discuss any school matters with members of the public, even if they offer disclaimers that they are speaking for themselves as private citizens and even if the issue in question has yet to come before their school board but could at some point in the future. Even posting a link to public information — with no additional commentary — would not immunize a school board member from an ethics investigation, the commission says.
Indeed, the commission has reprimanded school board members for things like writing opinion pieces endorsing other school board candidates or posting on Facebook about school overcrowding. 
Nazarene’s lawyer, Daniel Zahn, said the state’s interpretation of the School Ethics Act plainly violates the First Amendment. Zahn sounded mystified that state bureaucrats would want to limit the type of communication elected officials have with their constituents.
“It seems that for democracy to thrive we should be encouraging posts such as these that are engaging with constituents, asking them questions, respecting different viewpoints, and for the state to threaten sanctions for this type of respectful, powerful communication between elected officials and their constituents not only damages the First Amendment and free speech values, but also damages democracy and broader American values,” Zahn told me.
Anthony “Skip” Cimino has some thoughts on this. Camino represented the 14th Legislative District in the Assembly from 1988 to 1992, and he sponsored the School Ethics Act. Cimino told me he thinks the commission has interpreted the law incorrectly in Nazarene’s case.
“The act was really geared toward dealing with conflicts of interest and, quite frankly, people of ill repute doing things inappropriately,” he said.
Nazarene is an elected official who should have the right to talk to her constituents about school matters without violating the School Ethics Act, he added.
I am not opposed to strong ethics laws. But this is New Jersey. Not too long ago we had a sitting U.S. senator issue a public threat to anyone who dared challenge him at the ballot box. Last year, a state senator told an obvious lie to drum up support for a bill to gut our public records law. The members of our Legislature voted to give themselves gigantic pay raises with almost zero public input or debate. Yet there’s a very real chance a school board member will get an official reprimand from the state for asking people on Facebook what they think about tax increases. This is asinine.
